Hello,
I have a Samsung Galaxy S21 Ultra Unlocked phone which I bought from US. I enrolled to One UI 4 beta in US.  The software had been trouble free for me until I had to move back to India.
My carrier in India is Airtel which has good LTE coverage in my hometown. It supports VoLTE and WiFi calling as well. Since I moved to India, VoLTE or WiFi calling is not working for me. I rolled back to One UI 3.1 using Smart Switch and VoLTE and WiFi calling started working again. But, since I was already enrolled into One UI 4 beta, I got upgraded to the beta version again and VoLTE and WiFi calling stopped working. Interestingly, I used my Mint mobile sim card which I used in US and VoLTE and WiFi calling work with this card.
I contacted @USBetaModerator and he deregistered me from One UI 4 beta. I was able to downgrade to OneUI 3.1 again using Smart Switch. I was so relieved seeing VoLTE and WiFi calling working again.
Today, One UI 4 stable version was rolled out. I upgraded to this G998U1UEU4BUK7 version. To my frustration, VoLTE and WiFi calling stopped working again. This means that anyone who has a Samsung S21 series phone (or maybe any Samsung phone) with OneUI 4 will have the same problem. You won't be able to use it outside US.
I am assuming the network auto switch feature which Samsung introduced with One UI 4 is causing this issue. I had been trying to get some help from the Samsung team, but none has been able to help so far.
@sr14 is another user who is facing the exact same issue. 
@USBetaModerator @Samsungteam If you have a solution for this issue, let us know. Or at least advise the customers who plan to use their phones outside US not to upgrade to One UI 4.
Attaching the screenshots for everyone's reference. As you can see, in One UI 4, "IMS Registration" status is shown as "Not Registered" and "Voice over LTE" toggle is "OFF". In One UI 3.1, "IMS Registration" status is "Registered" and "Voice over LTE" toggle is "ON".
Users outside US: Please don't install OneUI 4 until this issue is fixed.
Thanks,
APS
OneUI 3.1 (VoLTE toggle is ON)
OneUI 3.1 (IMS Registered)
OneUI 4.0 (VoLTE toggle is OFF)
OneUI 4.0 (IMS Not Registered)

Hi Folks, just a PSA here.
Today I was able to wirelessly connect my S21Ultra to my Ram Uconnect 12" head unit using a device called AAWireless.
Setup was straight forward and quick and no settings needed to be changed on my phone as I already had Android Auto toggled on for Wifi.  My phone did need to BT pair with the AAWireless dongle but that was it.
Now every time I get into my truck my phone and Android Auto automatically connects to the AAWireless dongle and thus to my head unit.  Android Auto over WiFi does not display any of the USB connection issues we've been suffering through.
** If my response helps, please click on Like (Heart). If I resolved your issue also please click on Accept as a Solution so that others can benefit.

On December 23rd 2021, I regret to say that I fell into the trap of buying a new Samsung Galaxy s21 under Samsung's Trade-in program. They offered $500 of bonus credit and $55 when I sent in my perfectly working Samsung Galaxy s9.
Now I have been a Samsung customer for a long time - s5, s6, s7, s9 and now the s21. I have never disliked Samsung, in fact I always supported the brand. Until now.
Shortly after sending in my phone, I received an email from Asurion (Samsung's super scammy 3rd party who handles trade-ins) saying they'll be charging my bank card because I never sent it in.
I knew I had sent it, so I ignored it.
A few days later, I get another email from Asurion saying that I *Did* send it in, but it wasn't in a good enough condition, so they'll be charging me $100. Which is of course $45 MORE than the rebate they offered in the first place.
I offer an email rebuttal and ask for a photo. They then try to say they've changed it to $55 now, and lo and behold, a charge for $55 appears on my bank statement from Asurion.
Now I'm not one to make a big deal out of things but this really, really, really **bleep** me off. I would never have touched the s21 if I knew I would be scammed out of my phone. I loved my s9, and in many ways it was a better phone than the s21.
I would implore ANYONE who is reading this to not tempt fate, do NOT use the Tradeup program even if they offer you money, and DO NOT stay with Samsung because their customer service quality is so low, it's deeper than Hades.
No chat, call, or email support from Samsung is willing to help - they all just say "we can't help, you have to email Asurion". Sure mate, let me just ASK THE PEOPLE WHO STOLE MY MONEY for MY MONEY BACK. That will work.
So deeply disappointed in Samsung and this entire experience.

The S21 line are amazing phones. So why are sales so poor?  I read with interest the following article about Samsung scratching their heads trying to figure out why:
https://www.digitaltrends.com/mobile/samsung-galaxy-s21-sales-poor/
I normally upgrade to the latest S model every two years, when the latest and greatest arrives. I've done that for the S10+, S8+ and S6. But I didn't do it this year. Now it seems that I'm not the only one who has dropped the idea of upgrading.... and heres the key reason why we haven't bought the latest (when we normally would do so): 
Hey, Samsung, this is a no-brainer:  you seriously DOWNGRADED the phone's storage capability by removing expandable storage (i.e., an SD card). This is the same dumb thing that Apple does. The problem is Samsung has been dumber, because they removed something that was clearly one big reason why Apple customers have jumped ship to Samsung. And why Samsung customers have stayed.
Then Samsung insulted long-time Samsung mobile owners by not at least upgrading the base internal storage from 128 to 256 Gb to compensate for this.
That's two big dumb moves from Samsung. It's that sort of thing that is turning customers off. Samsung made the same dumb decision by removing expandable storage with the S6, but they got smart again and returned it to the S7.
Let's hope Samsung gets this. Storage is a majorly huge issue when it comes to a smartphone. And the #1 reason -- by far -- that more storage is needed is photos and videos. Now we have very high resolution photos (108 megapixels) and that means far bigger photo files and 8K video, meaning WAY bigger video files. And Samsung REMOVES expandable storage? Really, Samsung?
Samsung could argue, well photo and video taking runs so much better on internal storage. Granted. However, today's SD cards have incredible throughput. They are far more capabable than even a few years ago. Samsung has always been about consumer choice. Expandable storage is a critical choice.
Samsung.... smell the coffee. S21 sales are down because you did dumb. Either return expandable storage in next year's lineup (very smart) or at least increase the base storage if you insist on removing expandable storage (not as smart).
Hopefully, someone at Samsung with some decision making capability is paying attention to this. it's not rocket science. Let's get that expandable storage back, Samsung!

I've been with Samsung since the S3 and had the S4, note 4, S8,  S9+, S20+ and now the S21+. The note 4 had great spot in colors even with an older sensor than current phones. The S8 was the last one I had that actually took decent pictures. Starting with my s9, Samsung slowly started their saturation creep. The S20 series and S21 series pictures are just way too saturated. I don't know who in the marketing department did tests, but the pictures are too unrealistic to color in real life. We don't need overly greens, super blue skies and bright reds. The whole image in general is just too saturated. Comparing pics side by side taken with the S8, the S8 has much better pictures. The sensor is so much better on the S21, but ruined by post processing. A tad too much noise reduction making images muddy, and again, the over saturation. We shouldn't have to post process every picture.

I never had an iPhone and never want one, but their camera is light years ahead. I absolutely love how their images look, and they are LIFELIKE. No need for all the extra saturation. I wish Samsung took this seriously and make the pictures look like the S8 series again. Videos are the same mess. Too much saturation. Who thinks this is okay??

Pro mode makes the colors look better, but usually too dark. I also can never get a sharp picture using pro mode, no matter the settings. Always fuzzy, even on lightroom. I just want a decent phone picture, out of the box like apple. And I don't even like apple. If they changed their file structure, would probably get one.
Please Samsung, turn down the saturation on the photos and reduce noise reduction just a little bit.

Direct for VzW Tier 2:
Got it here, it seems I know why it will not allow the esim to activate here in our end. It says here that Dual sim or ESIM have device or line types that is eligible to be activated in the account. Samsung Galaxy S21 / S21+ / S21 Ultra 5G
SU11 or later (released 11/16/21)
S21 software version SP1A.210812.016. G991USQU4BUK7
S21+ software version SP1A.210812.016.G996USQU4BUk7
S21 Ultra software version SP1A.210812.016.G998USQU4BUK7
Mean while my Samsung Direct build is and is not supported: My current build: SP1A.210812.016.G996U1UEU4BUKF

I recently purchased a Samsung Galaxy S21 Ultra 5G. 
Being told that my new phone is Hearing Aid Compatible, I purchased Oticon More 3 minirite hearing aids. I am not profoundly deaf; I have moderate to severe hearing loss. 
I have since been told by an Oticon representative; the hearing aids are NOT compatible with my Samsung Galaxy S21 Ultra 5G.  He told me my phone was  “too high end”, and I should just wear the aids and not use the app/blue-tooth/remote benefits………what???
He said they are compatible with a Samsung Galaxy S21, but NOT the Galaxy S21 Ultra 5G.
Since they are not compatible, they only work “sometimes”, with the Oticon On app.
While blue-toothed to my phone, sometimes the right ear works, sometimes the left ear works, every now and then, they both work at the same time as they should.
When on the phone, calls are NEVER loud enough though the aids and the Oticon On app have them turned up as high as the aids and phone will go.  When driving, I can barely hear the other person at all.  In a very quiet office setting they are adequate, if the phone is turned up as loud as possible.
I have worked with my audiologist along with HER representative at Oticon.  I have driven back and forth to the audiologist’s office at least 8 times now (25 miles each way), I have only had the aids about three weeks. Settings have been changed, programs have been added and adjusted.  The aids are still not loud enough when on the phone and the left and right ear fade in and out whenever……
It was intimated that this is a Samsung problem and not an Oticon problem.  
Can this be true?? That it’s Samsung’s problem and not Oticon’s??
If my phone is NOT compatible with these hearing aids now, will there EVER be a software update that WILL make them compatible with my hearing aids and if so, when should I be expecting that update?
As anyone knows reading this, the hearing aids are not cheap, nor is a Samsung Galaxy S21 Ultra 5G. 
While once excited about the prospect of a new phone and hearing aids, I am disappointed and frustrated and I feel both Samsung and Oticon have totally misrepresented their products.
Is there ANYONE that can verify for me that my Samsung Galaxy S21 Ultra 5G is or is NOT compatible with Oticon More 3 minirite hearing aids.
If it is NOT compatible, can you please tell me which hearing aid brands AND models, DO work properly with this phone.
Thanks for reading and any help you can provide.

My Galaxy S21 Ultra will probably be my last Samsung phone. How can you refer to something as "ultra" if it is missing commonly used functionality of earlier phones.
No SPO2 sensor? So obviously Samsung is no longer interested in supporting personal health without forcing you to buy a watch. Added an Active 2 watch to my S10+a few years ago, because it supposedly supported automated health monitoring, but they did not activate the full sensor package until the Active 3, so while it did SOME things, there were other bits of functionality that never worked (e.g. ECG). According to the app, it's not supported in my location -- Colorado. I have to keep my old S10+ around for measuring blood oxygen levels.
No external memory card? No, the phone cannot qualify as "ultra" without that.
Pricing is a game for Samsung. A week or so before Thanksgiving, I was ordering my S21 Ultra and S Pen Pro, and it showed I was going to be saving over $700! I needed to help my wife with something, and when I came back to complete and submit the order, the page refreshed and the savings dropped to about $300. Customer Service people were no help, except to say I should order it on Black Friday, as that is the best deal. I watched the prices go up higher and higher until Black Friday, and the Black Friday sale price was still more than the original quoted price. On top of that, their military discount was not "30% through the end of the year" as indicated in the VA newsletter. I got 2.3%, which didn't even cover taxes. That doesn't spell appreciation to us.
The S21 Ultra is not the only thing that failed to live up to expectations. The S Pen Pro was advertised as being flexible enough to cover multiple devices. Again, a substandard product. It works on the S21 only -- and does not even provide support for capacitive contact, therefore it won't work on other devices -- Samsung or otherwise. 
To sum it up, Samsung has lost sight on what's important for so many people. These are not ultra devices, but diet versions of past products. The S Pen is not a "Pro" device if technology professionals like myself cannot use it across multiple devices. The price scam was the last straw for me. I've been recommending my friends and family compare Samsung devices to OnePlus devices, which are sold at a more reasonable price, if you don't mind sacrificing a little on camera megapixels. 
What a shame! Samsung started out so well. It's a shame they can't maintain it.

This is going to include quite a lot of information and will end up being a text wall. Read this all the way through before replying, as most of the things that will be suggested to me have already been considered, done, or are not available to me.
  I bought my S21 ULTRA (Unlocked) on 03/26/2021. I was using it on Verizon for several months with no issues outside of Verizon's awful coverage in my area. Last week (08/18/2021) the phone started to randomly shut itself off after dropping cell signal. I have the same exact thing happening with my AT&T sim as well, even though I have much better signal strength. From what I could tell I was not having overheating issues (I have see that floating around as a major issue of the entire S21 lineup), with my highest core temps being around 60C (should not be an issue for modern silicon to operate at that temperature), battery never exceeding 30 or 40C.
  I started digging around trying to find solutions on my own, here is what I tried:
Airplane mode on then off
Reset Network Settings (Probably done this about 100 times now)
Clear Cache (Via the bootloader menu - where you power down the device then power it on while holding the volume up button w/power)
Reseating the Sim 
Cleaning Sim card and Sim Tray/Slot (I have an anti-static blower made for cleaning electronics)
Factory Reset (Both in the settings menu and in the bootloader menu)
Nothing had worked, so I finally broke down and made the drive to my nearest authorized Samsung repair center (about an hour away). They "factory reset" the device (at a deeper level than what the user can do through software). That seemed to have fixed the issue. My drive up there had the device losing service multiple times and restart once, had almost perfect signal the whole way back. This was 2 days ago (8/23/2021).
Yesterday the device restarted itself unprompted and started dropping signal again. This was all while being virtually right beside a cell tower for my carrier, so signal strength would not be the cause.
Today I have been pretty much unable to use the device without being on wifi.
I have no issues with wifi connectivity. At all. When cellular works, I get expected speeds for my area.
I will note that I am not on the most current software for the device. I will be updating after I post this to see if Samsung issued a software patch for this issue (I am currently operating under the belief this is some software issue and not hardware).
I haven't had any sort of overheating problems with the phone. I've seen plenty of stuff floating around about that and I haven't seen it on my device.
I was wondering if anybody else is having this issue, and if so how many people might be affected...
Kinda defeats the purpose of a phone if it can't keep cellular connectivity!
The turn wifi on automatically only turns if off. When I leave the house it shuts off but does not turn on when I get home.

The only problem that I had with my Galaxy S21+ was that the fingerprint sensor rarely succeeded in unlocking my phone. The same fingerprint sensor unlocked my apps effortlessly - but was almost never able to unlock my phone. This made it miserable to use my phone. People laughed at me while I was trying unlock my phone. What good is a biometric if I can't get it to unlock my own phone?
My solution was to choose to unlock my phone with a PIN, while continuing to use the fingerprint sensor for my apps (including all my financial apps.) This solved another problem: I can now use a screen protector, which is something I could not do when I was trying to unlock the phone with its fingerprint sensor.
Although the fingerprint sensor is theoretically a stronger form of authentication, in the real world, it proved itself unusable as a method for unlocking my phone.

As a hobby DSLR photographer who has two granddaughters who seem to play one sport or another 3 days a week I tend to take a lot of action shots between Softball, Field Hockey and Ice Hockey.
I usually set my camera in Manual mode.  Set the shutter to a speed commensurate with both the sport and the lens I'm shooting with, and adjust the aperture so that I can get good isolation of the subject and then set the iso to auto to adapt to the varying lighting conditions.  I'd much rather have a photo which was a little noisy because of a high iso than one that was blurry because of too slow a shutter speed.
When I bought the Ultra I was immediately disappointed with the fact that there was no auto iso in Pro Mode which meant to shoot with a fast shutter, I had to continually manually adjust the iso as the lighting conditions changed.
I'm not sure when it happened, perhaps with Android 12, but now the iso can be set in auto or manual.
That means that using Pro Mode with the shutter set for my softball speed which is 1/640 using my f2.8 zoom, I can now set the shutter in the Camera pro mode for 1/750, AF=on, iso=auto and as I pan around for the shot the iso makes an attempt to keep up with the varying lighting conditions. It works pretty good though not as well as my Nikon and on an overcast day I thought the shots were consistently underexposed, so I bumped the exposure up to +1EV.
Now this was only my first few minutes playing with this and I know the below photo's are not good quality but they do show you that with Pro mode with auto iso and a high shutter speed, you can freeze a moving subject.
Here are two pics of cars traveling at about 55mph while I stand still and snap the shot as they pass through the frame.  The blue car exhibits motion blue and it was taken with the camera in Photo Mode....something we've all experienced with Photo Mode but I do feel that this is better than before.  The white car was taken in Pro mode and while both suffer with focus as I didn't tap the auto focus on, the white car does not exhibit motion blur.
Again, please excuse the poor quality but I hope to actually spend more than a minute or two playing with this over the next few days and hopefully I'll have something better to post.
  ** If my response helps, please click on Like (Heart). If I resolved your issue also please click on Accept as a Solution so that others can benefit.

Bill

Hello,
This is with regards to the S21 Ultra. I am not using a case and have removed all film from the device.
Has anyone noticed the background noise cancellation when using the speaker microphone is too aggressive in a VOLTE or video call? Any time I lay my phone flat and step > 3' away and talk out loud at an angle that is not directly pointed at the phone, the receiving party complains that my voice is too low or cutting in and out. It happens with multiple video apps but is less prominent in Duo. I wanted to see if anyone else has been experiencing similar issues. This has been happening on 2 different devices since my first replacement. There is no dust blocking the microphones. I believe the noise reduction processing in the configuration is too aggressive and there should be an option in the settings to reduce this effect globally across the phone. I recall older devices having such options but Samsung has removed it with more recent version of android.
After doing some searching there are mic processing parameters in audio_platform_info.xml located in /system/vendor/etc/ and particular frequency response values.

Apparently Samsung doesn't support WMA music files. Since "upgrading" to my s21 ultra my alarms don't go off half the time anymore making me late for work. Come to find out when you have an alarm app set to randomly play music it can see but doesn't play WMA files. So the screen lights up but no music plays when a WMA file is randomly selected. This really is as simple as them adding the codec to the Android OS. Their solution they've posted is find a player that supports it. And while my music app Power Amp does. It's not an alarm app and I can't find an alarm app that supports its own codecs. Their current response is unacceptable for such an expensive product theyve cut so many features off of. I spent alot of money on a phone that can't function as an alarm the way I want it to.

I am an avid user of Samsung phones. I currently have the S21 Ultra and love the phone. But year after year things come out on a new phone, only to have it gone on the next iteration. The items below to me would make the perfect phone that everyone would buy I believe.
Make everything just like the S21 Ultra with the below suggestions.
1. Keep S21 ultra brightness. This is great.
2. S21 cameras are great, but better camera system like pixel 6 pro.
3. Bring back the IR blaster infrared remote control system like in S6 model.
4. Bring back the Earphone jack.
5. FM radio - turn on the FM radio chip, not tied to a carrier turning on the chip. This is very useful in emergency situations when power and cell towers are out. Phone becomes worthless without it.
6. Better speakers and sound system. Make a top firing speaker in the top of the phone just like the bottom firing speaker, instead of using the ear piece. Add a sub-woofer. More bass and umpff at low and loud volumes. This suggestion (#6) alone would make me very happy.
7. Wider phone like the note series.
8. Finger print reader on back of phone like S9 model. Currently need 2 hands to use finger print reader.
9. Make phone rugged - don't need to get a case.
10. Bring back the notification light.
11. Flat screen - no curve on edge.
12. All phones unlocked. Should be up to user who they  connect to.
13. Solar charging. Phone charges in any light when not plugged into regular charger. This would be great in a survival situation.
14. Bring back expanded storage.

After the recent update to Snow Cone/Android 12/OneUI4, I'm seeing some issues/annoyances.
1. The text in notifications is a bit small. Yes, this can be adjusted with the overall zoom and font size, but that changes everything. Everything else is as it was and looks normal (I've tried changing the zoom and text size up and down in order to reset, as suggested in a few places)
I see a bunch of annoyances with the gallery app and sharing:
2. Where is the option to ALWAYS remove location from shared images? I recall this being an option before. I see there's an annoying/obscure way to do it per image (see screenshots), but I can't find an overall option to always remove location tags when sharing.
3. Where's the option to convert shared images from HEIF to jpg? Wasn't this an option before? Is this being done automatically now? What if someone wants to share HEIF images? 
4. What about the options for HDR/HEVC videos? Seems there was previously an option for converting these, as well. There's an option in Quick Share for videos, but...wouldn't that only apply to items shared through Quick Share?
5. Videos used to loop play. This was removed (before android 12). Why not give users an option for this? Many people would like to have this for an option, myself included.
5. The new share panel has positives and negatives. Quick share being permanently stuck in the first spot is stupid. Stop trying to make us use things that you (Samsung) think are cool. I will be seeing if disabling the Quick share package gets rid of this. When there are only 5 spots, each one is important
6. Why is it not possible to swipe up on this to see all of your apps? This sideways scroll and then the button to see more is just...bad. It was much simpler and intuitive before, with the swiping up. It's even more confusing as this current share panel looks like you can swipe it up, just like before. 
 To remove location you must click the little More> after which this pops up:
 If anyone sees options that I'm missing somewhere, please let me know.

If I am using my phone without power saving mode on I get 6-7 hours of screen on time and with power savings turned on I get 8-10 hours of screen on time.  I did come from the moto g power that got 16 hours of screen on time but the phone was uncomfortably heavy in the hand. I ALMOST traded in my s21 for the zflip 3 but 3 hours of screen on time is unacceptable especially if you plan to keep it for a few years with battery degradation. Samsung if your listening make a flip next year with solid battery life and I'll switch!! They could make a cheap model with less battery and a more expensive model with a bigger battery. My phone has stopped giving vibrations for notifications. It only vibrates for a call. I've looked at settings and I should be getting vibrations for notifications and I've tried resetting, restarting my phone and resetting my settings. Nothing has worked and I'm very upset with this new phone so far because of it.

I tried to find a place to give feedback, but it doesn't look like Samsung has any, I guess I will just post it here. Maybe it will be heard?
Samsung was always the phone that offered freedom to its users in terms of what they could do with their phone. They had expandable storage, changeable, batteries, more flexible software with unlockable bootloaders, cool features like Gear VR and DEX.
Over the years I have been a Galaxy fan boy, and have converted many lifelong apple users because it was a no brainer for some because of the freedom Samsung gave its users; even though Apple had better apps, better graphics, better cameras, better operating experience because of their inhouse software and hardware.
But over time, Samsung has slowly cut out all of the things that made them different from apple; otherwise known as UPS's (unique selling propositions) in marketing terms. And I understand why many of them needed to happen, such as the removable battery and headphone jack.
However the recent removal of the SD card slot may mark the final straw. Without it there just isn't enough to keep Samsung users from the better app support, performance, and 3rd party support of Apple. It seems the Samsung is trying to be like Apple, but when they do that, they will lose, because Apple has been doing it longer and better. 
With advanced high resolution camera's, it simply doesn't make since to have limited, non-expandable memory. A lot of people like me aren't in the city and cell reception isn't reliable, so cloud storage is not an option. But beyond storage space, removable storage is also very important if the phone becomes damaged or corrupted, because files can be saved by simply removing the card.
I get many don't use SD card slots, but including a SD slot doesn't hurt or turn anyone away. But removing it slaps many of Samsung loyal users in the face. The SD card slot is the reason my last 3 phones have been Samsung. I am not saying it needs to be on every device Samsung makes, but at least include it on the Ultra line, I don't mind paying a premium for the features that are important to me.
If the S22 Ultra doesn't have a SD slot, I will try to hold out one more year with my S8+ to see if the the S23 has it. But if the S23 doesn't have it, then users should decide between the Iphone or the Pixel for more pure operation experiences since Samsung has give up everything that made it unique. At that point there really isn't a reason for the Galaxy to exist.
I know there will be some that disagree, but this is my 2 cents. I don't think I am the only one.

I use Google Assistant on my S21 5G and the microphone icon in the keyboard options used to work well for speach-to-text purposes until I updated to Android 12 today. Since the update, when I tap the microphone icon, the keyboard disappears and I'm left with a an empty text box and no way to add input. When I go to the keyboard settings under General management the default keyboard shows as "Google Voice Typing [Legacy]" instead of "Samsung Keyboard." Once I change it back, the keyboard reappears. Also, at this point, my only 2 keyboard options are the two mentioned above.
I'm not sure which of these steps fixed my issue, but I started by disabling "Google Voice Typing [Legacy]" keyboard in my "Keyboard list and default" settings menu. Then I uninstalled Google Assistant, disabled my "Google" app, and restarted my phone. After the reboot, the "Google Voice Typing" option showed up in my "Keyboard list and default" settings menu without the "[Legacy]" annotation.  Now with this new keyboard enabled, when my Samsung Keyboard is open I can tap the keyboard icon in the lower right corner and change the input to Google Voice Typing for speech-to-text.
I hope this helps someone else who has this same issue. Also, after I got this working, I re-enabled my "Google" app and re-installed the "Google Assistant" app and I now have the Legacy keyboard option available again, but I left it disabled.

 Thanks!

 Longer version

Considering there is nothing special about the brown phone other than the color treatment, I was not happy with the month off but it is what it is. Then today I called Samsung US and a lady essentially told me that when I hit 60 days of not delivered product, they will ask me if I want to cancel the order or wait longer. I said, how much longer. Hi,
 If Location tags is enabled under Camera > Settings, then every time you open the camera app this prompt pops up:

Turn on Improve location accuracy?

To add location tags to your shots, turn on Improve location accuracy.

Not now | Turn on

I know I can simply disable Location tags to get rid of the message, but I like location tags. However, leaving location on all the time is very costly to battery life, and I don't need every single photo to be geotagged anyway, only certain ones. Also, it's much easier to enable/disable location from the quick settings menu when I want certain photos geotagged than to go to Camera > Settings > Location Tags. I just want to remove this prompt as it is a massive waste of time having to click "Not now" every time I want to use the camera. Sometimes it even causes me to miss wildlife shots.

Does anyone know how to get rid of this prompt without disabling Location Tags and leaving location on all the time? Some kind of "Do not display this message again" option?

Thanks,
Zach

I have a brand new Verizon S21 Ultra 256gb, ordered from Verizon, and it came with a free EB-U1200 wireless charger.  I used it for the first time last night, placing the phone on the charger on my nightstand, keeping the phone on for emergencies.
In the morning, it was at 100% as expected, but both the Phone and Charger were fairly warm to hot, which I didn't expect.  I assumed that once the phone reached 100%, it would switch to a trickle charge state, which wouldn't generate much heat.
I have another older Samsung charger (EP-PG950), used with my prior Note 8, and neither the Note 8 nor the charger ever got noticeably warm.  I haven't tried this charger overnight with the S21 Ultra yet.
So this raises several questions:
Should the phone and charger be that warm when left overnight?
Is it detrimental to battery life and quality to routinely leave it on a charger (wireless or wired) overnight?
Currently, I have "Fast Charging," "Super fast charging" and "Fast wireless charging" all enabled - would disabling some or all of these be best for overnight charging, and would this eliminate the heat problem?
I've researched this, and inevitably find conflicting information on "best practice" in this regard, but am curious to see what knowledgeable members here think, perhaps specifically with regard to the S21 Ultra.

Anyone else experiencing this issue, and anyone come across any solutions?
 Since the May release I’ve found that my unlocked snapdragon S21 Ultra 512GB has been experiencing significant focus issues on the main camera. It almost behaves like it already has a focus lock on something, and no attempts to focus on alternate subjects has any effect.
 If I switch to the Ultra-wide, the 3x tele, or the 10x tele, they all work exactly as expected and are in focus/can focus on other subjects with a tap. If I bring my hand up close to the lens and Focus Enhancer turns on (which I understand is just the phone switching to the ultra-wide), everything comes into focus, but then when I remove my hand it returns to the main camera and is out of focus.
Example of what I’m describing can be seen here
This has been happening on my phone since the May release, and so far I’ve had three releases since, none of which has seemed to improve this behavior. Currently running G998U1UEU4AUF5
 Troubleshooting steps attempted thus far:
 Usually when this happens, I’ve tried a handful of steps which inconsistently seem to help. The aforementioned step of holding my hand close to the lens so focus enhancer turns on and then pulling it away (so it switches back to the main camera) will often be enough for it to seemingly correct it’s focus lock and then the main camera will begin focusing properly again. This is what I attempt most of the time – and sometimes it works but not consistently.
I also force quit the camera app and clear the camera app’s cache. This has had inconsistent results as well. I’ve also tried wiping all data associated with the camera app – again with varied results in correcting the main camera focus issues. Most of the time I tend to just ‘miss the moment’ I was trying to capture, or if I’m really in a time crunch, find a way to make it work with either the ultra-wide or 3x lens.
 Anyone else experiencing this issue with the main camera? Anyone have any more reliable steps for correcting the issue when it occurs?

So I've had MANY Samsung devices in my day. It's a bit of a love/hate relationship with the brand. Sometimes there are hits and other times there are straight up misses.
I bought a S20 Ultra in 2020 and the camera glass cracked, developed a hole, and condensation eventually killed the device. Instead of paying the insane price of repair, I was so dissatisfied with performance of the camera in that $1400 device, I chalked it up to a paperweight and got a Pixel 3a XL. When I tell you that the $350 Pixel produce more consistent and better quality photos than my Galaxy S20 Ultra, I mean it. So I rocked the 3a XL for about a year until the S21 was announced. While the camera performance was spectacular, the device was slow and annoying. So, instead of going all in like I did the Ultra, I decided to get a S21 5G instead. 

While the 120Hz OLED is beautiful, performance is mega, and the hardware is gorgeous, the camera generally disappoints. The images are inexplicably blurry, the shutter speed snaps photos much later after you press the shutter button, and zooming in on photos only shows graininess and lack of sharpness. And don't get me started on the selfie camera. It still tries to "beautify" my face, even with the effects and filters turned off.

I thought I was misremembering my experience on my Pixel, so I pulled it out for some comparison shots and turns out, I wasn't. The photos from the Pixel 3a XL were much more pleasing out of auto-mode than on my S21 5G. Not just sorta better, but NOTICIBLY better. I was also more easily able to whip my phone out of my pocket, take a shot, and assume it was fine, than immediate reviewing it on my Galaxy to see if I needed to take it again, and maybe again, to finally get a usable shot.

It is frustrating listening to the marketing hype and show that Samsung puts on every year only to be outperformed by a $350 device in this area ESPECIALLY since Samsung likes to use marketing photos that are seemingly DSLR-like quality.

That's all to say, what am I doing wrong with my S21 in auto-mode to make the photos experience so challenged?

Original Post:
I would love to see a built in option to have my screen wake for notifications. I see that for some reason, a good amount of people seem to be requesting the opposite of what I want to be a feature on One UI for the S21 series. Coming from iOS, I am used to my phone screen waking briefly when I receive a notification, as this is a default setting. 
To me, this is an awesome feature because it allows me to quickly look at my screen, without having to interact with it, and see what notification I just received. Because of my job, I always keep my phone on vibrate only and it doesn't make sense to switch back and forth so it can ring after work hours, since I may forget to switch back to vibrate and my phone might start going off while I'm in an important call or meeting. 
I also have a Galaxy Watch 3, and I was surprised to see that in the settings, there is an included option to "turn on the watch screen when  Notifications are received." This only helps me when I am wearing the watch so when I don't have it on, I have to constantly check to see if I missed any notifications. If the phone is near me, I sometimes don't hear/feel it vibrate, but I'd the screen turns on, it immediately gets my attention. 
To note, I mostly use Whatsapp for messaging and to my knowledge, the Messages app is the only one that wakes the screen when messages come in. 
If this setting can be enabled for the watch and for messages, why not have it as an option for the phone itself? 
It is clear that Samsung is trying to capture a portion of the iOS market and it will only help them more to have some features that people coming from iOS are accustomed to. Even if it is only enabled in vibrate mode, that would already be huge for people that are used to having this feature on their iOS devices.

I'm not completely certain what the original appeal was beyond that or why the likes of LG or other equivalent brands of the day got no love from me back then. Fast forward to today, and I know exactly why. The second Samsung Galaxy smart phone I owned was the Galaxy S5, and that phone was a large part of why Samsung earned my loyalty. But the relationship would not be completely solidified until the company severely <edit> in the design of that iterations replacement. 
  When the Galaxy S6 line was released, I was beside myself with frustration, confusion, and basically severe disappointment. While the new S6 designs were the impitus of those negative reactions, the focus of my ire was squarely on the company itself for basically designing out the very features that compelled me to purchase the S5 in the first place. They decided to eliminate the removable/ replaceable battery back when carrying around an extra fully charged battery for your phone was commonplace. They decided to eliminate the ¼" headset jack, doing so before quality Bluetooth headsets were hardly affordable and Bluetooth LE wasn't even a thing. And then they decided to eliminate the MicroSD card dock way before the concept of reliable cloud storage was anywhere near as widespread as it needed to be. 
  There were more features that were curtailed and/ or eliminated in the S6 series, but these were the three that I found to represent the common underlying offense which lead to Samsung choosing to make these changes, an error that is far too commonly committed by manufacturers and service providers across the economy. Samsung simply chose that the S6 series was going to be the pivot point where they would abandon the needs and desires of their core global customer base, and instead of offering hardware that met the needs of this customer base, they would now begin to mimick the designs of their most challenging industry competitor, the iPhone. The Samsung Galaxy mobile hardware division simply lost its way and tried to be something they were not, and which their customers didn't want them to be.
  Life's most valuable lessons are almost always delivered in the most painful experiences possible. There isn't a company in existence that hasn't dropped the ball in some way or fashion. It's actually a healthy process to go through for most, assuming the after action review of the failure is analyzed and corrective actions are taken. As is the case with individuals and companies alike, there is no greater catalyst for improvement or the gaining of knowledge then that which results from a complete and total failure. It's all about how that failure is handled and leveraged.
  Once the anemic S6 features, or lack there of, were released and those like me who had been excited to upgrade but quickly became resigned to keeping the older phones we had, it wasn't long before the magnitude of the design failures started to become clear to Samsung leadership. I was only one of probably millions of disappointed people who were ready to buy the new S6, but decided not to. While I'll never know how many were compelled to voice our frustrations directly to the company via a very terse, yet well crafted email, I'm willing to bet it was a whole lotta people. 
  We were Samsung customers for many reasons, one of the most significant being that Samsung was NOT iPhone. We chose Samsung because they didn't try to push it's customers into recent innovations in technology which were both excessivly priced and still unproven, something iPhone is always doing. We chose Samsung because they offered phones that were designed with utility and user customizable features that empowered us to make the phone work best for our specific needs, not a one size fits all mantra like iPhone. So what on Earth compelled Samsung to try and be the very company they were valued as not being? 
  My loyalty was cemented a year later when Samsung released the next iteration of the Galaxy line, the S7 series. It was one of the first times I had been watching closely enough to see what it looked like when a multinational corporation chooses to listen to it's customers' collective needs, and I was beyond impressed. They didn't bring back everything, removable batteries were never going to remain mainstream, especially as the technology becomes more and more capable with each iteration. But sure enough, they heard us, they listened to what we were saying, and they reversed course with the vast majority of features. The fact that I would quickly grow to despise my S7 Edge on account of the Edge feature, Samsung was back on track!
  After beating <edit> the S7 everyday in my steering wheel everyday when the stupid Edge screen would come into contact with a part of my hand and erroneously do things to enrage me, I knew I would never purchase another phone with that utterly worthless gimmicky feature. The problem was, they decided to make that Edge thing a standard design feature with all of the following year's S8 series phones, much to my dismay. But patience paid dividends for me when I read about the mid-cycle release of the S8 Active model. 
  I had never really looked at the Active versions of the older iterations, and I'm not even sure I was aware of them. But this S8 Active had everything I could want, a bigger battery, no stupid Edge screen, and something I wouldn't realize about the phone until I had it for a few weeks. One of the many reasons I'm never going to own an iPhone as a primary cell phone is an experience I had with an older iPhone 5. I don't remember why I had it, but I do remember accidentally dropping onto a hardwood floor from a height no greater than 2½ feet up. From my perspective watching the phone drop in slow motion, I still am amazed at how the moment the frame came into contact with the floor, the screen didn't just crack. No, the screen seemed to enthusiastically explode out as though it had been waiting to do so it's entire life, and in an instant, the iPhone went from useful to useless. Done. 
  I've dropped plenty of Samsung Galaxy phones throughout my life, all from differing heights, some faring better then others, but none exploding in glee like that iPhone. That said, the durability of that S8 Active was ridiculously high, and trust me when I say this, I tested that thing on more than once occasion. In at least one bout of ginger rage triggered by the phone not functioning how I wanted it to, it survived without a scratch after being overhand day pitched into a wall about 6 feet away, the sheetrock suffering all that damage (I've since repaired it because it wasn't the sheetrock's fault!). 
  I would be compelled to maintain that S8 Active for years beyond it's dated technology because Samsung, for whatever reason, decided to do away with all Active variants in any Galaxy iterations that would come after the S8. Why, why do you do these things Samsung? The S21 Ultra is a beast which almost has the feel of an Active model once tucked into the Spigen case I use for all my phones. But I bet there is plenty of demand for an S21 Active if you made one. No, the corporate rugged XCover model that sorta looks like an Active doesn't rate. My <edit> 3 year old S8 Active had a more powerful processor and better features than that underdeveloped model offered. I want all the Gucci hotness you guys stuffed into this ridiculously capable S21 Ultra offered in a <edit> housing that can easily shrug off an occasional overhand fast pitch into a wall because I know you guys can build it. If you do this and relaunch the Active models, I'll be a Samsung customer for life. If you don't do it, I'll still be a Samsung customer for life, so I'm really not in a position to negotiate. Do it to make the exploding iPhones screens look even more stupid!

I am very pleased to say that my struggles with the Galaxy S21 fingerprint sensor are OVER  ...  and no visit to UbreakIFixit was needed. That may come as some relief to those who suffered through my anger and frustration in earlier posts. As a token of my appreciation to you all for putting up with me, I am glad to share what I learned.
It certainly could be possible that your fingerprint sensor is, in fact, defective. This is, after all, a new phone in its first months of production. But you should try these steps first, before making a visit to Ubreak.
You should watch a few videos of people who really know how to work with the fingerprint sensor successfully. Watch how they register their fingers; watch how they use the sensor to actually sign in. That was my big "Aha" moment. So that's the way you're supposed to hold your finger! That's the way you're supposed to press on the sensor! Who knew?
And on the subject of your finger: Don't use your finger - use your thumb. You're giving the sensor more skin to read.
Once you have successfully registered your thumb(s) or your finger(s) don't stop there. Go ahead and practice unlocking your phone with the fingerprint sensor. Do it several times. The more often you do this (up to a point, probably) the faster the sensor recognizes your thumb/finger.
Now that you're getting the hang of it, watch a video from a Fingerprint Master, like "Jimmy is Promo" https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r9v3H1dOyQc to learn secrets for making the fingerprint sensor work faster. This stuff really works.
At last, I have unlocked the secrets of the Galaxy S21 fingerprint sensor! Now, instead of using my middle finger to talk to my phone, I use my thumbs to unlock it.

Not sure if anyone else is experiencing random delays in notifications.

I.E. I'm at home, no notifications come through on the phone (or text messages) and the moment I get off WiFi they come through en mass. It also happens with some cell towers, when I hit a new cell tower, notifications come through en mass. This seems to rule out the network but rather the software is the issue.

All,
I had posted about my WiFi Calling turning itself off. For some reason after a Moderator replied to my post, I can no longer reply. It keeps telling me that either I didn't verify my email address when I signed up (I'm getting email replies when someone posts), or something else I can't remember. So here we go.
The Moderator was likely blaming my WiFi router, and telling me I'd probably need to buy an amp ($400 for a good one), or buy a newer router.  I'm not about to do that after spending money on an expensive S21+.  I shouldn't need to. According to US Cellular's maps, I'm in a strong signal area and should even get 5G. Nope. Never seen the 5G icon at my home. And someone I see "No Cellular Service". 
My Asus AC66R is fully updated to the latest firmware and put's out a strong -35dBm signal. And I also have repeaters in the house where I need them. Oh, and I work at a large company that has about 1000 repeaters that are less than a year old, plus a state-of-the-art WiFi system in the building. My WiFI Calling turns itself off there too. There's several repeaters just in the lab I work in. 
Further, he stated that WiFi Calling is a Carrier specific function and so it has to be a carrier problem, not a phone problem. NOT !  WiFi Calling "ability" is carrier specific. The "function" of being able to turn it on or off IS WITHIN THE PHONE'S SOFTWARE. The carrier has no ability to turn my WiFi Calling switch on or off. Strike two from Samsung Support.
Last night while trying to turn it on, it kept asking me for my 911 info which I'd already put in a few days back. Every time I'd press on ACCEPT, it would loop back and ask me to put it in again ... over and over and over. It would never turn on the WiFi Calling then. That smells to me like a software issue.  But I'll admit, it could be a hardware issue too. 
I just got off the phone with US Cellular's technicians, and heard two very interesting things:
1. The problem with WiFi Calling does not happen with ANY other brand of phone they sell ... only Samsung. He rattled off about 6 other brands they sell ... no WiFi Calling issues with any of them. Only Samsung. It is a known issue that they have talked to Samsung about many times according to this technician. 
2. The weak signal receive that is making me need to use WiFi Calling (never had to before with any other phone I used including a Samsung S8+) is ALSO a known problem with the S21 phones. They've also talked to Samsung about this.
I wish I'd known all of this prior to buying a Samsung S21+.  And the other mistake I made was buying the phone directly from Samsung,  having to deal with support staff there that don't know what they're talking about, and shipping phones back and forth.
Oh ... I'm an RF Engineering Technician for a large Aerospace company. I don't know much about cell phones. But I do understand software and RF signals.

Either way, any help is appreciated for the simple fact that time was taken to read/reply, :).
A few things:
- The phone can send and receive calls when it is not casting.
- The devices in question include both Samsung devices: Samsung's Galaxy & Tizen Smart TV.

Messaging Issue I purchased the S21+ through Spectrum and was not receiving some text from my contacts.I could get most but not all. (and no the contacts in question weren't using Apple phones) After hours of research I finally figured out I was not receiving text from my contacts that use RCS messaging (chat features). I could send them text but their reply wasn't coming back through. (unless they clicked on the reply text and selected sms) I was just wondering if anyone else had this issue. I have done a lot of troubleshooting such as clearing the cache and the data on messages, resetting the network on the phone, having Spectrum reset the network on the sim, putting phone in safe mode, resetting the phone, ect.... I'm also open to any advice or input on this situation. Kinda wondering if it is just my phone or a programming or network issue. PS. I upgraded from Note 9 to S21, since I rarely used the S-Pen and since I thought it would be nice to have 5G service. After the first 2 days, I almost returned it, since the battery drain seemed to be 2X more that my Note 9. 
The final solution was two fold... (1) went in to settings and turned if background services on EVERY application that was not essential, excluding  Email, LinkedIn, etc. and (2) went in to settings and told every app to close when not in use.
Prior to doing thus the phone ran hot during "normal use" and after the wireless carrier and Samsung support suggested running it for 2 days without 5G. My response to them was "seriously, you want me to turn off the 5G functionality that was the reason I bought the S21.
By limiting  background services and closing applications when not in use,, my battery life is acceptable, but many believe the 5G radio draws more power than 4G, but that is yet to be confirmed.

@samsung978531 New S21 ATT variant purchased from Samsung.com 1/27/21, activated on ATT network 2/3/21. ATT unlock database does not recognize IMEI as an ATT device. ATT claims data received from Samsung omitted this device. Samsung claims that unlock codes were provided at time of manufacturer and the issue is with ATT. While I was on the phone with advanced ATT support, they called Samsung support to request an unlock code per CTIA guidance. That request was denied. 

In researching this issue online, it appears to be a common problem with carrier locked devices sold by Samsung.com. I have spoken now to 9 support people at ATT over 3 days. They physically cannot unlock this device without data sharing from Samsung. Meanwhile, Samsung CS pins the blame on ATT. I purchased this device at retail and it is under warranty. ATT agrees that it is eligible for unlock and are willing to unlock the device but cannot without updated data from Samsung. As a customer, I have been caught in the middle. I have sent details via Twitter messenger to Samsung Mobile US with no reply. I have spent hours on the phone with Samsung CS without being offered any solution, only finger pointing. I have provided enough detail for Samsung engineering to work with ATT to provide data necessary for a carrier unlock code for this device. 

If I RMA the device back to Samsung, I will be out a phone and will be forced to waste half a day to set up a new device with no guarantee that it won't have the same issue. There is clearly a communication problem and/or inconsistent policy between Samsung and ATT. I have also read similar accounts with other carriers. IMO, there should be an option to purchase a carrier variant which is unlocked from the factory. There is zero reason for these devices to be locked since they are purchased at retail and not subject to ATT payment plan or other ATT subsidized pricing dependent on service contracts. The unbranded US factory unlocked variant of this device likely does not support ATT features such as HD Voice, Call Protect, wifi calling, etc. 

Simply because the IMEI of this device appears in the Samsung internal database does not mean that it appears in ATT's unlock code database. I see this as a database management and data sharing glitch that potentially impacts thousands of customers. Most will not realize that they have purchased a device incapable of unlock until their Samsung warranty has expired.

Please do not suggest that I contact ATT customer support which I have exhausted in spades. I am asking Samsung to contact ATT and provide a joint solution. This should happen seamlessly without involving the customer. I feel like I have been dragged into a bad marriage.

Iris unlocking is faster than facial recognition, more secure, works in the dark, regardless of wearing a mask, and usually regardless of wearing glasses.

Facial recognition does not work in the dark, or if wearing a mask, 
Fingerprint recognition does not work with dry skin or gloves.

Dropping iris scanning is like getting a new 70" smart TV in 2021 that only supports 1080p. If people weren't using it, it's because they didn't know about it.

By the way, I did search for any previous post on this, and didn't find any. The site does not allow searching a specific forum, only everything, and did not allow only showing results with all keywords. All the results I found were for other models.

I finally figured this out. Open the existing Calendar item you want to copy. In the lower left corner of your screen, choose the Copy icon. The existing Calendar item changes into an edit state. Modify the date in the existing Calendar item and save it. All done! Your existing Calendar item remains unchanged and you now have a copy of the existing item on the new date that you saved! Note that I tried this on a Galaxy S21+ G5, but I think it works on all recent Galaxy models.

I am a low vision user and I use a few of the accessibility features on Samsung Galaxy s21. I just wanted to suggest feedback for the chatheads if at all possible. Right now they're almost perfect to me. The main thing here is comparing it to Facebook Messenger; while if I'm having a prolonged conversation, I'll keep the chathead up. However, often times I'm just replying quickly and will dismiss it immediately. 

The problem here is that Messenger remembers where the chathead was before dismissal and will default to that location when the chathead comes back up after being dismissed. Unfortunately, One UI 3.1's chathead function will always come up on the left of the screen, which is difficult for a righty like myself.

My only other gripe is that I really LOVE the pop up conversation here. It's great to be able to reply, see previous messages and go over the previous character limit without needing to open the app entirely. I just wish we had that functionality without chatheads. Seeing somthing similar to iOS would be ideal; a quick reply through a button via the notification banner that brings up the same interphase introduced with these systemwide chatheads.

Hi everyone,
 Have you preordered a new phone? Share with us! It helps to keep track together, to get an idea on when they ship, what models are being delivered sooner and in general, help each other deal with the long wait for a new phone!
 Which model, storage size, color did you order? 
Carrier variant or unlocked?
Are you trading in your current device?
What did you order with your pre-order bonus? 
 And finally, what do you like the most about these new phone? What made you want to order it right away? Or are you still thinking about it? Do you have any concerns?
 I was thinking about it for few days, but finally placed an order today!
 S21 Ultra (The camera, screen and battery life are the most exciting features to me)
128GB (I know, never enough, but I looked at my current usage and since pictures and videos are backed up to Google Photos, it should actually be plenty. 256GB for only $50 more was tempting, but it wasn't available in the color I want and the other color ships 3 weeks later too!)
Phantom Silver (Just like silver or white phones)
AT&T (Usually get my carrier model to take advantage of advanced network features)
Trading in Note 20 Ultra (Yes, it's a tough call since the Note is an amazing device, but their pre-order offers are too good! Couldn't resist)
Used my Pre-Order Bonus to get a Galaxy Watch Active2, a Leather case and a Rugged case. The new Buds Pro were tempting, but I already have 4 pairs of Samsung earbuds (Buds, Buds+, Live, IconX) so I figured a new smartwatch will be more useful!

My s21 ultra (snapdragon, unlocked) wifi range is really poor. Mobile data works perfectly, but on wifi I have to be right next to the router to get anything over 2 mbps consistently. 

Here's what I've tried: 
Reset network settings
Boot into safe mode (issue persists in safe mode)
Factory reset phone and opted out of smart switch after reset
Turned off 5g
Tried with/without bluetooth
Turned off Google Location Accuracy Restarted router
Changed router frequency channel
Reset router to default ssttings
Changed MAC address to phone MAC

I do not see any messages like "Connected Without Internet". The connection just says "Connected". Very occasionally some apps will cause a message along the lines of "WiFi unstable, waiting for stable wifi before continuing"

Every other device in the home connects just fine, including my previous phone s7 edge. On my s7 edge, I can be on the complete other side of the house and still get reasonable speeds. 

When enabling mobile data tethering on another device, I can connect to that device's hotspot with a reasonable speed.

When checking the speed directly next to the router, I see good speeds, as expected with any device right next to a router. A couple feet or more away from the router, and the speeds are abyssmal as described. It seems the WiFi range on my device has huge exponential drop-off after a couple feet.

My router is single-band (2.4GHz only). The model is MI424WR rev 1.0. I pay for 100 mbps, my s7 edge gets around 25 mbps consistently, but the s21 ultra gets around 1mbps on average, and very commonly even less than that.

Due to COVID I will likely not be able to test my device on anyone else's router but my own anytime soon.

Is it safe to say the device is defective? Do you recommend I RMA this device? Anyone else with similar issues have advice? Sure one can argue I have an "older" router but I would expect this device to at least match the network performance of my S7 edge. It does not make sense to me to say this is an issue with the router.
